    Source:   
    def process_sonar_file(
        sl_filepath: Path, # Path to sl2 or sl3 file
        folder_out: Path, # Output folder for exported files
        to_crs: str = "epsg:28992" # Target CRS
        ) -> None:
        "Process sonar file: extract height, convert to GeoDataFrame, clean, and export"
        msrmnt_height = extract_height(sl_filepath)
        gdf = slx2gdf(sl_filepath, to_crs=to_crs)
        gdf_clean = clean_gdf(gdf, msrmnt_height)
        export_gdf(gdf_clean, sl_filepath.stem, folder_out)

>
> You can use the `argparse` module to create a command-line interface.
> Hereâ€™s a function that wraps your `process_sonar_file`:
>
> ``` python
> import argparse
>
> def main():
>     parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="Convert sonar files (sl2/sl3) to CSV and shapefile")
>     parser.add_argument('input', type=Path, help="Path to sl2 or sl3 file")
>     parser.add_argument('output', type=Path, help="Output folder for exported files")
>     parser.add_argument('--crs', default='epsg:28992', help="Target CRS (default: epsg:28992)")
>     args = parser.parse_args()
>     process_sonar_file(args.input, args.output, args.crs)
> ```
>
> This will allow you to run it from the command line like:
>
> ``` bash
> python your_script.py input.sl3 output_folder --crs epsg:28992
> ```
